text: In the third year of the reign of King Jehoiakim of Judah, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came to Jerusalem and besieged it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord gave King Jehoiakim of Judah into his power, as well as some of the vessels of the house of God. These he brought to the land of Shinar, and he placed the vessels in the treasury of his gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king commanded his palace master Ashpenaz to bring some of the Israelites of the royal family and of the nobility:
speaker: Narrator

text: young men without physical defect and handsome, versed in every branch of wisdom, endowed with knowledge and insight, and competent to serve in the king’s palace; they were to be taught the literature and language of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king assigned them a daily portion of the royal rations of food and wine. They were to be educated for three years, so that at the end of that time they could be stationed in the king’s court.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among them were Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, from the tribe of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The palace master gave them other names: Daniel he called Belteshazzar, Hananiah he called Shadrach, Mishael he called Meshach, and Azariah he called Abednego.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Daniel resolved that he would not defile himself with the royal rations of food and wine, so he asked the palace master to allow him not to defile himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now God granted Daniel favor and compassion from the palace master.
speaker: Narrator

text: The palace master said to Daniel, “I am afraid of my lord the king; he has appointed your food and your drink. If he should see you in poorer condition than the other young men of your age, you would endanger my head with the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Daniel asked the guard whom the palace master had appointed over Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please test your servants for ten days. Let us be given vegetables to eat and water to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can then compare our appearance with the appearance of the young men who eat the royal rations and deal with your servants according to what you observe.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he agreed to this proposal and tested them for ten days.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of ten days it was observed that they appeared better and fatter than all the young men who had been eating the royal rations.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the guard continued to withdraw their royal rations and the wine they were to drink and gave them vegetables.
speaker: Narrator

text: To these four young men God gave knowledge and skill in every aspect of literature and wisdom; Daniel also had insight into all visions and dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of the time that the king had set for them to be brought in, the palace master brought them into the presence of Nebuchadnezzar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the king spoke with them. Among them all, no one was found to compare with Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah; therefore they were stationed in the king’s court.
speaker: Narrator

text: In every matter of wisdom and understanding concerning which the king inquired of them, he found them ten times better than all the magicians and enchanters in his whole kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Daniel continued there until the first year of King Cyrus.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year of Nebuchadnezzar’s reign, Nebuchadnezzar dreamed such dreams that his spirit was troubled and his sleep left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king commanded that the magicians, the enchanters, the sorcerers, and the Chaldeans be summoned to tell the king his dreams. When they came in and stood before the king,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to them, “I have had such a dream that my spirit is troubled by the desire to understand it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Chaldeans said to the king (in Aramaic), “O king, live forever! Tell your servants the dream, and we will reveal the interpretation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king answered the Chaldeans, “This is a public decree: if you do not tell me both the dream and its interpretation, you shall be torn limb from limb, and your houses shall be laid in ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do tell me the dream and its interpretation, you shall receive from me gifts and rewards and great honor. Therefore tell me the dream and its interpretation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered a second time, “Let the king first tell his servants the dream, then we can give its interpretation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king answered, “I know with certainty that you are trying to gain time because you see the decree from me is firm:
speaker: Narrator

text: if you do not tell me the dream, there is but one verdict for you. You have agreed to speak lying and misleading words to me until things take a turn. Therefore, tell me the dream, and I shall know that you can give me its interpretation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Chaldeans answered the king, “There is no one on earth who can reveal what the king demands! In fact, no king, however great and powerful, has ever asked such a thing of any magician or enchanter or Chaldean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The thing that the king is asking is too difficult, and no one can reveal it to the king except the gods, whose dwelling is not with mortals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of this the king flew into a violent rage and commanded that all the wise men of Babylon be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The decree was issued, and the wise men were about to be executed, and they looked for Daniel and his companions, to execute them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Daniel responded with prudence and discretion to Arioch, the king’s chief executioner, who had gone out to execute the wise men of Babylon;
speaker: Narrator

text: he asked Arioch, the royal official, “Why is the decree of the king so urgent?” Arioch then explained the matter to Daniel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Daniel went in and requested that the king give him time and he would tell the king the interpretation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Daniel went to his home and informed his companions, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, of the matter
speaker: Narrator

text: and told them to seek mercy from the God of heaven concerning this mystery, so that Daniel and his companions might not perish with the rest of the wise men of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the mystery was revealed to Daniel in a vision of the night, and Daniel blessed the God of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Daniel said:
“Blessed be the name of God from age to age,
    for wisdom and power are his.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He changes times and seasons,
    deposes kings and sets up kings;
he gives wisdom to the wise
    and knowledge to those who have understanding.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
To you, O God of my ancestors,
    I give thanks and praise,
for you have given me wisdom and power
    and have now revealed to me what we asked of you,
    for you have revealed to us what the king ordered.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Daniel went to Arioch, whom the king had appointed to destroy the wise men of Babylon, and said to him, “Do not destroy the wise men of Babylon; bring me in before the king, and I will give the king the interpretation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Arioch quickly brought Daniel before the king and said to him: “I have found among the exiles from Judah a man who can tell the king the interpretation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Daniel, whose name was Belteshazzar, “Are you able to tell me the dream that I have seen and its interpretation?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel answered the king, “No wise men, enchanters, magicians, or diviners can show to the king the mystery that the king is asking,
speaker: Narrator

text: but there is a God in heaven who reveals mysteries, and he has disclosed to King Nebuchadnezzar what will happen at the end of days. Your dream and the visions of your head as you lay in bed were these:
speaker: Narrator

text: To you, O king, as you lay in bed, came thoughts of what would be hereafter, and the revealer of mysteries disclosed to you what is to be.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for me, this mystery has not been revealed to me because of any wisdom that I have more than any other living being, but in order that the interpretation may be known to the king and that you may understand the thoughts of your mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You were looking, O king, and there appeared a great statue. That statue was huge, its brilliance extraordinary; it was standing before you, and its appearance was frightening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The head of that statue was of fine gold, its chest and arms of silver, its midsection and thighs of bronze,
speaker: Narrator

text: its legs of iron, its feet partly of iron and partly of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text: As you looked on, a stone was cut out, not by human hands, and it struck the statue on its feet of iron and clay and broke them in pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the iron, the clay, the bronze, the silver, and the gold were all broken in pieces and became like the chaff of the summer threshing floors, and the wind carried them away, so that not a trace of them could be found. But the stone that struck the statue became a great mountain and filled the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “That was the dream; now we will tell the king its interpretation.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, O king, the king of kings—to whom the God of heaven has given the kingdom, the power, the might, and the glory,
speaker: Narrator

text: into whose hand he has given human beings wherever they live, the wild animals of the field, and the birds of the air and whom he has established as ruler over them all—you are the head of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: After you shall arise another kingdom inferior to yours and yet a third kingdom of bronze, which shall rule over the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there shall be a fourth kingdom, strong as iron; just as iron crushes and smashes everything, it shall crush and shatter all these.
speaker: Narrator

text: As you saw the feet and toes partly of potter’s clay and partly of iron, it shall be a divided kingdom, but some of the strength of iron shall be in it, as you saw the iron mixed with the clay.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the toes of the feet were part iron and part clay, so the kingdom shall be partly strong and partly brittle.
speaker: Narrator

text: As you saw the iron mixed with clay, so will they mix with one another in marriage, but they will not hold together, just as iron does not mix with clay.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the days of those kings the God of heaven will set up a kingdom that shall never be destroyed, nor shall this kingdom be left to another people. It shall crush all these kingdoms and bring them to an end, and it shall stand forever,
speaker: Narrator

text: just as you saw that a stone was cut from the mountain not by hands and that it crushed the iron, the bronze, the clay, the silver, and the gold. The great God has informed the king what shall be hereafter. The dream is certain and its interpretation trustworthy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Nebuchadnezzar fell on his face, worshiped Daniel, and commanded that a grain offering and incense be offered to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Daniel, “Truly, your God is God of gods and Lord of kings and a revealer of mysteries, for you have been able to reveal this mystery!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king promoted Daniel, gave him many great gifts, and made him ruler over the whole province of Babylon and chief prefect over all the wise men of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel made a request of the king, and he appointed Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego over the affairs of the province of Babylon. But Daniel remained at the king’s court.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Nebuchadnezzar made a golden statue whose height was sixty cubits and whose width was six cubits; he set it up on the plain of Dura in the province of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Nebuchadnezzar sent for the satraps, the prefects, and the governors, the counselors, the treasurers, the justices, the magistrates, and all the officials of the provinces to assemble and come to the dedication of the statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the satraps, the prefects, and the governors, the counselors, the treasurers, the justices, the magistrates, and all the officials of the provinces assembled for the dedication of the statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up. When they were standing before the statue that Nebuchadnezzar had set up,
speaker: Narrator

text: the herald proclaimed aloud, “You are commanded, O peoples, nations, and languages,
speaker: Narrator

text: that when you hear the sound of the horn, pipe, lyre, trigon, harp, drum, and entire musical ensemble, you are to fall down and worship the golden statue that King Nebuchadnezzar has set up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever does not fall down and worship shall immediately be thrown into a furnace of blazing fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, as soon as all the peoples heard the sound of the horn, pipe, lyre, trigon, harp, drum, and entire musical ensemble, all the peoples, nations, and languages fell down and worshiped the golden statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Accordingly, at this time certain Chaldeans came forward and denounced the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to King Nebuchadnezzar, “O king, live forever!
speaker: Narrator

text: You, O king, have made a decree, that everyone who hears the sound of the horn, pipe, lyre, trigon, harp, drum, and entire musical ensemble, shall fall down and worship the golden statue,
speaker: Narrator

text: and whoever does not fall down and worship shall be thrown into a furnace of blazing fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are certain Jews whom you have appointed over the affairs of the province of Babylon: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. These men pay no heed to you, O king. They do not serve your gods, and they do not worship the golden statue that you have set up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nebuchadnezzar in furious rage commanded that Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego be brought in, so they brought those men before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuchadnezzar said to them, “Is it true, O Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, that you do not serve my gods and you do not worship the golden statue that I have set up?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if you are ready, when you hear the sound of the horn, pipe, lyre, trigon, harp, drum, and entire musical ensemble, you should fall down and worship the statue that I have made. But if you do not worship, you shall immediately be thrown into a furnace of blazing fire, and who is the god who will deliver you out of my hands?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego answered the king, “O Nebuchadnezzar, we have no need to present a defense to you in this matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: If our God whom we serve is able to deliver us from the furnace of blazing fire and out of your hand, O king, let him deliver us.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if not, be it known to you, O king, that we will not serve your gods and we will not worship the golden statue that you have set up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nebuchadnezzar was so filled with rage against Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego that his face was distorted. He ordered the furnace heated up seven times more than was customary
speaker: Narrator

text: and ordered some of the strongest guards in his army to bind Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego and to throw them into the furnace of blazing fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men were bound, still wearing their tunics, their trousers, their hats, and their other garments, and they were thrown into the furnace of blazing fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because the king’s command was urgent and the furnace was so overheated, the raging flames killed the men who lifted Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the three men, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, fell down, bound, into the furnace of blazing fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Nebuchadnezzar was astonished and rose up quickly. He said to his counselors, “Was it not three men that we threw bound into the fire?” They answered the king, “True, O king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “But I see four men unbound, walking in the middle of the fire, and they are not hurt, and the fourth has the appearance of a god.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuchadnezzar then approached the door of the furnace of blazing fire and said, “Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, servants of the Most High God, come out! Come here!” So Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego came out from the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the satraps, the prefects, the governors, and the king’s counselors gathered together and saw that the fire had not had any power over the bodies of those men; the hair of their heads was not singed, their tunics were not scorched, and not even the smell of fire came from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuchadnezzar said, “Blessed be the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, who has sent his angel and delivered his servants who trusted in him. They disobeyed the king’s command and yielded up their bodies rather than serve and worship any god except their own God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I make a decree: Any people, nation, or language that utters blasphemy against the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego shall be torn limb from limb and their houses laid in ruins, for there is no other god who is able to deliver in this way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king promoted Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego in the province of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Nebuchadnezzar to all peoples, nations, and languages that live throughout the earth: May you have abundant prosperity!
speaker: Narrator

text: The signs and wonders that the Most High God has worked for me I am pleased to recount.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How great are his signs,
    how mighty his wonders!
His kingdom is an everlasting kingdom,
    and his sovereignty is from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Nebuchadnezzar, was living at ease in my home and prospering in my palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw a dream that frightened me; my fantasies in bed and the visions of my head terrified me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I made a decree that all the wise men of Babylon should be brought before me, in order that they might tell me the interpretation of the dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the magicians, the enchanters, the Chaldeans, and the diviners came in, and I told them the dream, but they could not tell me its interpretation.
speaker: Narrator

text: At last Daniel came in before me—he who was named Belteshazzar after the name of my god and who is endowed with a spirit of the holy gods—and I told him the dream:
speaker: Narrator

text: “O Belteshazzar, chief of the magicians, I know that you are endowed with a spirit of the holy gods and that no mystery is too difficult for you. Hear the dream that I saw, and tell me its interpretation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Upon my bed this is what I saw:
    there was a tree at the center of the earth,
    and its height was great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tree grew great and strong,
    its top reached to heaven,
    and it was visible to the ends of the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its foliage was beautiful,
    its fruit abundant,
    and it provided food for all.
The animals of the field found shade under it,
    the birds of the air nested in its branches,
    and from it all living beings were fed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I continued looking, in the visions of my head as I lay in bed, and there was a holy watcher coming down from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He cried aloud and said:
‘Cut down the tree and chop off its branches;
    strip off its foliage and scatter its fruit.
Let the animals flee from beneath it
    and the birds from its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But leave its stump and roots in the ground,
    with a band of iron and bronze,
    in the tender grass of the field.
Let him be bathed with the dew of heaven,
    and let his lot be with the animals
    in the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let his mind be changed from that of a human,
    and let the mind of an animal be given to him.
    And let seven times pass over him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sentence is rendered by decree of the watchers,
    the decision is given by order of the holy ones,
in order that all who live may know
    that the Most High is sovereign over the kingdom of mortals;
he gives it to whom he will
    and sets over it the lowliest of human beings.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the dream that I, King Nebuchadnezzar, saw. Now you, Belteshazzar, declare the interpretation, since all the wise men of my kingdom are unable to tell me the interpretation. You are able, however, for you are endowed with a spirit of the holy gods.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Daniel, whose name was Belteshazzar, was severely distressed for a while. His thoughts terrified him. The king said, “Belteshazzar, do not let the dream or the interpretation terrify you.” Belteshazzar answered, “My lord, may the dream be for those who hate you and its interpretation for your enemies!
speaker: Narrator

text: The tree that you saw, which grew great and strong so that its top reached to heaven and was visible to the whole earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: whose foliage was beautiful and its fruit abundant, and which provided food for all, under which animals of the field lived and in whose branches the birds of the air had nests—
speaker: Narrator

text: it is you, O king! You have grown great and strong. Your greatness has increased and reaches to heaven, and your sovereignty to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whereas the king saw a holy watcher coming down from heaven and saying, ‘Cut down the tree and destroy it, but leave its stump and roots in the ground, with a band of iron and bronze, in the grass of the field, and let him be bathed with the dew of heaven, and let his lot be with the animals of the field, until seven times pass over him’—
speaker: Narrator

text: this is the interpretation, O king, and it is a decree of the Most High that has come upon my lord the king:
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall be driven away from human society, and your dwelling shall be with the wild animals. You shall be made to eat grass like oxen, you shall be bathed with the dew of heaven, and seven times shall pass over you, until you have learned that the Most High has sovereignty over the kingdom of mortals and gives it to whom he will.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it was commanded to leave the stump and roots of the tree, your kingdom shall be reestablished for you from the time that you learn that Heaven is sovereign.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, O king, may my counsel be acceptable to you: atone for your sins with righteousness and your iniquities with mercy to the oppressed, so that your prosperity may be prolonged.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All this came upon King Nebuchadnezzar.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of twelve months he was walking on the roof of the royal palace of Babylon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the king said, “Is this not magnificent Babylon, which I have built as a royal capital by my mighty power and for my glorious majesty?”
speaker: Narrator

text: While the words were still in the king’s mouth, a voice came down from heaven: “O King Nebuchadnezzar, to you it is declared: The kingdom is taken from you!
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall be driven away from human society, and your dwelling shall be with the animals of the field. You shall be made to eat grass like oxen, and seven times shall pass over you, until you have learned that the Most High has sovereignty over the kingdom of mortals and gives it to whom he will.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately the sentence was fulfilled against Nebuchadnezzar. He was driven away from human society, he ate grass like oxen, and his body was bathed with the dew of heaven, until his hair grew as long as eagles’ feathers and his nails became like birds’ claws.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When that period was over, I, Nebuchadnezzar, lifted my eyes to heaven, and my reason returned to me.
I blessed the Most High
    and praised and honored the one who lives forever.
For his sovereignty is an everlasting sovereignty,
    and his kingdom endures from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the inhabitants of the earth are accounted as nothing,
    and he does what he wills with the host of heaven
    and the inhabitants of the earth.
There is no one who can stay his hand
    or say to him, “What have you done?”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time my reason returned to me, and my majesty and splendor were restored to me for the glory of my kingdom. My counselors and my lords sought me out, I was reestablished over my kingdom, and still more greatness was added to me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: King Belshazzar made a great feast for a thousand of his lords, and he was drinking wine in the presence of the thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under the influence of the wine, Belshazzar commanded that they bring in the vessels of gold and silver that his father Nebuchadnezzar had taken out of the temple in Jerusalem, so that the king and his lords, his wives, and his concubines might drink from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought in the vessels of gold that had been taken out of the temple, the house of God in Jerusalem, and the king and his lords, his wives, and his concubines drank from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They drank the wine and praised the gods of gold and silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately the fingers of a human hand appeared and began writing on the plaster of the wall of the royal palace, next to the lampstand. The king was watching the hand as it wrote.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king’s face turned pale, and his thoughts terrified him. His limbs gave way, and his knees knocked together.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king cried aloud to bring in the enchanters, the Chaldeans, and the diviners, and the king said to the wise men of Babylon, “Whoever can read this writing and tell me its interpretation shall be clothed in purple, have a chain of gold around his neck, and rank third in the kingdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the king’s wise men came in, but they could not read the writing or tell the king the interpretation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Belshazzar became greatly terrified, and his face turned pale, and his lords were perplexed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The queen, when she heard the discussion of the king and his lords, came into the banquet hall. The queen said, “O king, live forever! Do not let your thoughts terrify you or your face grow pale.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a man in your kingdom who is endowed with a spirit of the holy gods. In the days of your father he was found to have enlightenment, understanding, and wisdom like the wisdom of the gods. Your father, King Nebuchadnezzar, made him chief of the magicians, enchanters, Chaldeans, and diviners,
speaker: Narrator

text: because an excellent spirit, knowledge, and understanding to interpret dreams, explain riddles, and solve problems were found in this Daniel, whom the king named Belteshazzar. Now let Daniel be called, and he will reveal the interpretation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Daniel was brought in before the king. The king said to Daniel, “So you are Daniel, one of the exiles of Judah, whom my father the king brought from Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have heard of you that a spirit of the gods is in you and that enlightenment, understanding, and excellent wisdom are found in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the wise men, the enchanters, have been brought in before me to read this writing and tell me its interpretation, but they were not able to reveal the interpretation of the matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have heard that you can give interpretations and solve problems. Now if you are able to read the writing and tell me its interpretation, you shall be clothed in purple, have a chain of gold around your neck, and rank third in the kingdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Daniel answered in the presence of the king, “Let your gifts be for yourself, or give your rewards to someone else! Nevertheless I will read the writing to the king and let him know the interpretation.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, O king, the Most High God gave your father Nebuchadnezzar kingship, greatness, glory, and majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because of the greatness that he gave him, all peoples, nations, and languages trembled and feared before him. He killed those he wanted to kill, kept alive those he wanted to keep alive, honored those he wanted to honor, and degraded those he wanted to degrade.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when his heart was lifted up and his spirit was hardened so that he acted proudly, he was deposed from his kingly throne, and his glory was stripped from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was driven from human society, and his mind was made like that of an animal. His dwelling was with the wild asses, he was fed grass like oxen, and his body was bathed with the dew of heaven, until he learned that the Most High God has sovereignty over the kingdom of mortals and sets over it whomever he will.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you, Belshazzar his son, have not humbled your heart, even though you knew all this!
speaker: Narrator

text: You have exalted yourself against the Lord of heaven! The vessels of his temple have been brought in before you, and you and your lords, your wives, and your concubines have been drinking wine from them. You have praised the gods of silver and gold, of bronze, iron, wood, and stone, which do not see or hear or know, but the God in whose power is your very breath and to whom belong all your ways, you have not honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So from his presence the hand was sent and this writing was inscribed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is the writing that was inscribed: mene, tekel, and parsin.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the interpretation of the matter: mene: God has numbered the days of your kingdom and brought it to an end;
speaker: Narrator

text: tekel: you have been weighed on the scales and found wanting;
speaker: Narrator

text: peres: your kingdom is divided and given to the Medes and Persians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Belshazzar gave the command, and Daniel was clothed in purple, a chain of gold was put around his neck, and a proclamation was made concerning him that he should rank third in the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very night Belshazzar, the Chaldean king, was killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Darius the Mede received the kingdom, being about sixty-two years old.
speaker: Narrator

text: It pleased Darius to set over the kingdom one hundred twenty satraps, stationed throughout the whole kingdom,
speaker: Narrator

text: and over them three administrators, one of whom was Daniel; to these the satraps gave account, so that the king might suffer no loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon Daniel distinguished himself above the other administrators and satraps because an excellent spirit was in him, and the king planned to appoint him over the whole kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the administrators and the satraps tried to find grounds for complaint against Daniel in connection with the kingdom. But they could find no grounds for complaint or any corruption, because he was faithful, and no negligence or corruption could be found in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men said, “We shall not find any ground for complaint against this Daniel unless we find it in connection with the law of his God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the administrators and satraps conspired and came to the king and said to him, “O King Darius, live forever!
speaker: Narrator

text: All the administrators of the kingdom, the prefects and the satraps, the counselors and the governors are agreed that the king should establish an ordinance and enforce an interdict, that whoever prays to any god or human, for thirty days, except to you, O king, shall be thrown into the den of lions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, O king, establish the interdict and sign the document, so that it cannot be changed, according to the law of the Medes and the Persians, which cannot be revoked.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore King Darius signed the document and interdict.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although Daniel knew that the document had been signed, he continued to go to his house, which had windows in its upper room open toward Jerusalem, and to get down on his knees three times a day to pray to his God and praise him, just as he had done previously.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then those men watched and found Daniel praying and seeking mercy before his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they approached the king and said concerning the interdict, “O king! Did you not sign an interdict, that anyone who prays to any god or human, within thirty days, except to you, O king, shall be thrown into the den of lions?” The king answered, “The thing stands fast, according to the law of the Medes and Persians, which cannot be revoked.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they responded to the king, “Daniel, one of the exiles from Judah, pays no attention to you, O king, or to the interdict you have signed, but he is saying his prayers three times a day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard the charge, he was very much distressed. He was determined to save Daniel, and until the sun went down he made every effort to rescue him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the conspirators came to the king and said to him, “Know, O king, that it is a law of the Medes and Persians that no interdict or ordinance that the king establishes can be changed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king gave the command, and Daniel was brought and thrown into the den of lions. The king said to Daniel, “May your God, whom you faithfully serve, deliver you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: A stone was brought and laid on the mouth of the den, and the king sealed it with his own signet ring and with the signet ring of his lords, so that nothing might be changed concerning Daniel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king went to his palace and spent the night fasting; no entertainment was brought to him, and sleep fled from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then at dawn, the king got up and at first light hurried to the den of lions.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came near the den where Daniel was, he cried out anxiously to Daniel, “O Daniel, servant of the living God, has your God whom you faithfully serve been able to deliver you from the lions?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel then said to the king, “O king, live forever!
speaker: Narrator

text: My God sent his angel and shut the lions’ mouths so that they would not hurt me, because I was found blameless before him; also before you, O king, I have done no wrong.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king was exceedingly glad and commanded that Daniel be taken up out of the den. So Daniel was taken up out of the den, and no kind of harm was found on him because he had trusted in his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king gave a command, and those who had maliciously accused Daniel were brought and thrown into the den of lions—they, their children, and their wives. Before they reached the bottom of the den, the lions overpowered them and broke all their bones in pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Darius wrote to all peoples and nations of every language throughout the whole world: “May you have abundant prosperity!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I make a decree, that in all my royal dominion people shall tremble and fear before the God of Daniel:
For he is the living God,
    enduring forever.
His kingdom shall never be destroyed,
    and his dominion has no end.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: So this Daniel prospered during the reign of Darius and the reign of Cyrus the Persian.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first year of King Belshazzar of Babylon, Daniel had a dream and visions of his head as he lay in bed. Then he wrote down the dream:
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Daniel, saw in my vision by night the four winds of heaven stirring up the great sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: and four great beasts came up out of the sea, different from one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first was like a lion and had eagles’ wings. Then, as I watched, its wings were plucked off, and it was lifted up from the ground and made to stand on two feet like a human being, and a human mind was given to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Another beast appeared, a second one, that looked like a bear. It was raised up on one side, had three tusks in its mouth among its teeth, and was told, “Arise, devour many bodies!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, as I watched, another appeared, like a leopard. The beast had four wings of a bird on its back and four heads, and dominion was given to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this I saw in the visions by night a fourth beast, terrifying and dreadful and exceedingly strong. It had great iron teeth and was devouring, breaking in pieces, and stamping what was left with its feet. It was different from all the beasts that preceded it, and it had ten horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was considering the horns when another horn appeared, a little one that came up among them. Three of the original horns were plucked up from before it. There were eyes like human eyes in this horn and a mouth speaking arrogantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As I watched,
thrones were set in place,
    and an Ancient One took his throne;
his clothing was white as snow
    and the hair of his head like pure wool;
his throne was fiery flames,
    and its wheels were burning fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A stream of fire issued
    and flowed out from his presence.
A thousand thousands served him,
    and ten thousand times ten thousand stood attending him.
The court sat in judgment,
    and the books were opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: I watched then because of the noise of the arrogant words that the horn was speaking. And as I watched, the beast was put to death and its body destroyed and given over to be burned with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the rest of the beasts, their dominion was taken away, but their lives were prolonged for a season and a time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As I watched in the night visions,
I saw one like a human being
    coming with the clouds of heaven.
And he came to the Ancient One
    and was presented before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To him was given dominion
    and glory and kingship,
that all peoples, nations, and languages
    should serve him.
His dominion is an everlasting dominion
    that shall not pass away,
and his kingship is one
    that shall never be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for me, Daniel, my spirit was troubled within me, and the visions of my head terrified me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I approached one of the attendants to ask him the truth concerning all this. So he said that he would disclose to me the interpretation of the matter:
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for these four great beasts, four kings shall arise out of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the holy ones of the Most High shall receive the kingdom and possess the kingdom forever—forever and ever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I desired to know the truth concerning the fourth beast, which was different from all the rest, exceedingly terrifying, with its teeth of iron and claws of bronze, and which devoured and broke in pieces and stamped what was left with its feet;
speaker: Narrator

text: and concerning the ten horns that were on its head, and concerning the other horn that came up and before which three others had fallen—the horn that had eyes and a mouth that spoke arrogantly and that seemed greater than the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked, that horn made war with the holy ones and was prevailing over them,
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Ancient One came; then judgment was given for the holy ones of the Most High, and the time arrived when the holy ones gained possession of the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what he said: “As for the fourth beast,
there shall be a fourth kingdom on earth
    that shall be different from all the other kingdoms;
it shall devour the whole earth
    and trample it down and break it to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for the ten horns,
out of this kingdom ten kings shall arise,
    and another shall arise after them.
This one shall be different from the former ones
    and shall put down three kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall speak words against the Most High,
    shall wear out the holy ones of the Most High,
    and shall attempt to change the ritual calendar and the law,
and they shall be given into his power
    for a time, two times, and half a time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the court shall sit in judgment,
    and his dominion shall be taken away,
    to be consumed and totally destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The kingship and dominion
    and the greatness of the kingdoms under the whole heaven
    shall be given to the people of the holy ones of the Most High;
their kingdom shall be an everlasting kingdom,
    and all dominions shall serve and obey them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Here the account ends. As for me, Daniel, my thoughts greatly terrified me, and my face turned pale, but I kept the matter in my mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of the reign of King Belshazzar a vision appeared to me, Daniel, after the one that had appeared to me at first.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the vision I saw myself in Susa the capital, in the province of Elam, and I was by the Ulai Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: I looked up and saw a ram standing beside the gate. It had two horns. Both horns were long, but one was longer than the other, and the longer one came up second.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw the ram charging westward and northward and southward. All beasts were powerless to withstand it, and no one could rescue from its power; it did as it pleased and became strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I was watching, a male goat appeared from the west, coming across the face of the whole earth without touching the ground. The goat had a horn between its eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: It came toward the ram with the two horns that I had seen standing beside the gate, and it ran at it with savage force.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw it approaching the ram. It was enraged against it and struck the ram, breaking its two horns. The ram did not have power to withstand it; it threw the ram down to the ground and trampled upon it, and there was no one who could rescue the ram from its power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the male goat grew exceedingly great, but at the height of its power the great horn was broken, and in its place there came up four prominent horns toward the four winds of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of one of them came another horn, a little one, which grew exceedingly great toward the south, toward the east, and toward the beautiful land.
speaker: Narrator

text: It grew as high as the host of heaven. It threw down to earth some of the host and some of the stars and trampled on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even against the prince of the host it acted arrogantly; it took the regular burnt offering away from him and overthrew the place of his sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of wickedness, the host was given over to it together with the regular burnt offering; it cast truth to the ground and kept prospering in what it did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I heard a holy one speaking, and another holy one said to the one who spoke, “For how long is this vision concerning the regular burnt offering, the transgression that makes desolate, and the giving over of the sanctuary and host to be trampled?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he answered him, “For two thousand three hundred evenings and mornings; then the sanctuary shall be restored to its rightful state.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When I, Daniel, had seen the vision, I tried to understand it. Then someone appeared standing before me, having the appearance of a man,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I heard a human voice by the Ulai, calling, “Gabriel, help this man understand the vision.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he came near where I stood, and when he came, I became frightened and fell prostrate. But he said to me, “Understand, O mortal, that the vision is for the time of the end.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was speaking to me, I fell into a trance, face to the ground; then he touched me and set me on my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Listen, and I will tell you what will take place later in the period of wrath, for it refers to the appointed time of the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the ram that you saw with the two horns, these are the kings of Media and Persia.
speaker: Narrator

text: The male goat is the king of Greece, and the great horn between its eyes is the first king.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the horn that was broken, in place of which four others arose, four kingdoms shall arise from his nation but not with his power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the end of their rule,
    when the transgressions have reached their full measure,
a king of bold countenance shall arise,
    skilled in intrigue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall grow strong in power,
    shall cause fearful destruction,
    and shall succeed in what he does.
He shall destroy the powerful
    and the people of the holy ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By his cunning
    he shall make deceit prosper under his hand,
    and in his own mind he shall be great.
Without warning he shall destroy many
    and shall even rise up against the Prince of princes.
But he shall be broken, and not by human hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The vision of the evenings and the mornings that has been told is true. As for you, seal up the vision, for it refers to many days from now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I, Daniel, was overcome and lay sick for some days; then I arose and went about the king’s business. But I was dismayed by the vision and did not understand it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first year of Darius son of Ahasuerus, by birth a Mede, who became king over the realm of the Chaldeans,
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Daniel, perceived in the books the number of years that, according to the word of the Lord to the prophet Jeremiah, must be fulfilled for the devastation of Jerusalem, namely, seventy years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I turned to the Lord God to seek an answer by prayer and supplication with fasting and sackcloth and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I prayed to the Lord my God and made confession, saying,
“Ah, Lord, great and awesome God, keeping covenant and steadfast love with those who love you and keep your commandments,
speaker: Narrator

text: we have sinned and done wrong, acted wickedly and rebelled, turning aside from your commandments and ordinances.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have not listened to your servants the prophets, who spoke in your name to our kings, our princes, and our ancestors, and to all the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Righteousness is on your side, O Lord, but open shame, as at this day, falls on us, the people of Judah, the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and all Israel, those who are near and those who are far away, in all the lands to which you have driven them because of the treachery that they have committed against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Open shame, O Lord, falls on us, our kings, our princes, and our ancestors because we have sinned against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the Lord our God belong mercy and forgiveness, but we have rebelled against him
speaker: Narrator

text: and have not obeyed the voice of the Lord our God by following his laws, which he set before us by his servants the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All Israel has transgressed your law and turned aside, refusing to obey your voice. So the curse and the oath written in the law of Moses, the servant of God, have been poured out upon us because we have sinned against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has confirmed his words that he spoke against us and against our rulers by bringing upon us a calamity so great that what has been done against Jerusalem has never before been done under the whole heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as it is written in the law of Moses, all this calamity has come upon us. We did not entreat the favor of the Lord our God, turning from our iniquities and reflecting on his fidelity.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord kept watch over this calamity until he brought it upon us. Indeed, the Lord our God is right in all that he has done, for we have disobeyed his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, O Lord our God, who brought your people out of the land of Egypt with a mighty hand and made your name renowned even to this day—we have sinned, we have done wickedly.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, in view of all your righteous acts, let your anger and wrath, we pray, turn away from your city Jerusalem, your holy mountain; because of our sins and the iniquities of our ancestors, Jerusalem and your people have become a disgrace among all our neighbors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, O our God, listen to the prayer of your servant and to his supplication, and for your own sake, Lord, let your face shine upon your desolated sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Incline your ear, O my God, and hear. Open your eyes and look at our desolation and the city that bears your name. We do not present our supplication before you on the ground of our righteousness but on the ground of your great mercies.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, hear; O Lord, forgive; O Lord, listen and act and do not delay! For your own sake, O my God, because your city and your people bear your name!”
speaker: Narrator

text: While I was speaking and was praying and confessing my sin and the sin of my people Israel and presenting my supplication before the Lord my God on behalf of the holy mountain of my God,
speaker: Narrator

text: while I was speaking in prayer, the man Gabriel, whom I had seen before in a vision, came to me in swift flight at the time of the evening sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came and said to me, “Daniel, I have now come out to give you wisdom and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the beginning of your supplications a word went out, and I have come to declare it, for you are greatly beloved. So consider the word and understand the vision:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Seventy weeks are decreed for your people and your holy city: to finish the transgression, to put an end to sin, and to atone for iniquity, to bring in everlasting righteousness, to seal both vision and prophet, and to anoint a most holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know therefore and understand: from the time that the word went out to restore and rebuild Jerusalem until the time of an anointed prince, there shall be seven weeks, and for sixty-two weeks it shall be built again with streets and moat, but in a troubled time.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the sixty-two weeks, an anointed one shall be cut off and shall have nothing, and the troops of the prince who is to come shall destroy the city and the sanctuary. Its end shall come with a flood, and to the end there shall be war. Desolations are decreed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall make a strong covenant with many for one week, and for half of the week he shall make sacrifice and offering cease, and in their place shall be a desolating sacrilege until the decreed end is poured out upon the desolator.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of King Cyrus of Persia a word was revealed to Daniel, who was named Belteshazzar. The word was true, and it concerned a great conflict. He understood the word, having received understanding in the vision.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time I, Daniel, had been mourning for three weeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: I had eaten no rich food, no meat or wine had entered my mouth, and I had not anointed myself at all, for the full three weeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twenty-fourth day of the first month, as I was standing on the bank of the great river (that is, the Tigris),
speaker: Narrator

text: I looked up and saw a man clothed in linen, with a belt of gold from Uphaz around his waist.
speaker: Narrator

text: His body was like beryl, his face like lightning, his eyes like flaming torches, his arms and legs like the gleam of burnished bronze, and the sound of his words like the roar of a multitude.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Daniel, alone saw the vision; the people who were with me did not see the vision, though a great trembling fell upon them, and they fled and hid themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I was left alone to see this great vision. My strength left me, and my complexion grew deathly pale, and I retained no strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I heard the sound of his words, I fell into a trance, face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then a hand touched me and roused me to my hands and knees.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Daniel, greatly beloved, pay attention to the words that I am going to speak to you. Stand on your feet, for I have now been sent to you.” So while he was speaking this word to me, I stood up trembling.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Do not fear, Daniel, for from the first day that you set your mind to gain understanding and to humble yourself before your God, your words have been heard, and I have come because of your words.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the prince of the kingdom of Persia opposed me twenty-one days. So Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me, and I left him there with the prince of the kingdom of Persia
speaker: Narrator

text: and have come to help you understand what is to happen to your people at the end of days. For there is a further vision for those days.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was speaking these words to me, I turned my face toward the ground and was speechless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one in human form touched my lips, and I opened my mouth to speak and said to the one who stood before me, “My lord, because of the vision such pains have come upon me that I retain no strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: How can my lord’s servant talk with my lord? For I am exhausted; no strength remains in me, and no breath is left in me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again one in human form touched me and strengthened me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Do not fear, greatly beloved; you are safe. Be strong and courageous!” When he spoke to me, I was strengthened and said, “Let my lord speak, for you have strengthened me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Do you know why I have come to you? Now I must return to fight against the prince of Persia, and when I am through with him, the prince of Greece will come.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I am to tell you what is inscribed in the book of truth. There is no one with me who contends against these princes except Michael, your prince.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for me, in the first year of Darius the Mede, I stood up to support and strengthen him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now I will announce the truth to you. Three more kings shall arise in Persia. The fourth shall be far richer than all of them, and when he has become strong through his riches, he shall stir up all against the kingdom of Greece.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a warrior king shall arise who shall rule with great dominion and take action as he pleases.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while still rising in power, his kingdom shall be broken and divided toward the four winds of heaven but not to his posterity nor according to the dominion with which he ruled, for his kingdom shall be uprooted and go to others besides these.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the king of the south shall grow strong, but one of his officers shall grow stronger than he and shall rule a realm greater than his own realm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After some years they shall make an alliance, and the daughter of the king of the south shall come to the king of the north to ratify the agreement. But she shall not retain her power, and his offspring shall not endure. She shall be given up, she and her attendants and her child and the one who supported her.
“In those times
speaker: Narrator

text: a branch from her roots shall rise up in his place. He shall come against the army and enter the fortress of the king of the north, and he shall take action against them and prevail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even their gods, with their idols and with their precious vessels of silver and gold, he shall carry off to Egypt as spoils of war. For some years he shall refrain from attacking the king of the north;
speaker: Narrator

text: then the latter shall invade the realm of the king of the south but will return to his own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “His sons shall wage war and assemble a multitude of great forces that shall advance like a flood and pass through and again shall carry the war as far as his fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moved with rage, the king of the south shall go out and do battle against the king of the north, who shall muster a great multitude, but the multitude shall be given over to his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the multitude has been carried off, his heart shall be exalted, and he shall overthrow tens of thousands, but he shall not prevail.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the king of the north shall again raise a multitude larger than the former, and after some years he shall advance with a great army and abundant supplies.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In those times many shall rise against the king of the south. The lawless among your own people shall lift themselves up in order to fulfill the vision, but they shall fail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of the north shall come and throw up siegeworks and take a well-fortified city. And the forces of the south shall not stand, not even his picked troops, for there shall be no strength to resist.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he who comes against him shall take the actions he pleases, and no one shall withstand him. He shall take a position in the beautiful land, and all of it shall be in his power.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall set his face to come with the strength of his whole kingdom. He shall make peace with him and shall give him a woman in marriage, in order to destroy the kingdom, but it shall not succeed or be to his advantage.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward he shall turn to the coastlands and shall capture many, but a commander shall put an end to his insolence; indeed, he shall turn his insolence back upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he shall turn back toward the fortresses of his own land, but he shall stumble and fall and shall not be found.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then shall arise in his place one who shall send an official for the glory of the kingdom, but within a few days he shall be broken, though not in anger or in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his place shall arise a contemptible person on whom royal majesty had not been conferred; he shall come in suddenly and seize the kingdom through intrigue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Armies shall be utterly swept away and broken before him, and the prince of the covenant as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after an alliance is made with him, he shall act deceitfully and become strong with a small party.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly he shall come into the richest parts of the province and do what none of his predecessors had ever done, lavishing plunder, spoil, and wealth on them. He shall devise plans against strongholds but only for a time.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall stir up his power and determination against the king of the south with a great army, and the king of the south shall wage war with a much greater and stronger army. But he shall not succeed, for plots shall be devised against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who eat of the royal rations shall break him, his army shall be swept away, and many shall fall slain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two kings, their minds bent on evil, shall sit at one table and exchange lies. But it shall not succeed, for there remains an end at the time appointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall return to his land with great wealth, but his heart shall be set against the holy covenant. He shall work his will and return to his own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At the time appointed he shall return and come into the south, but this time it shall not be as it was before.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ships of Kittim shall come against him, and he shall lose heart and withdraw. He shall be enraged and take action against the holy covenant. He shall turn back and come to an understanding with those who forsake the holy covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Forces sent by him shall occupy and profane the temple and fortress. They shall abolish the regular burnt offering and set up the desolating sacrilege.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will flatter with smooth words those who violate the covenant, but the people who are loyal to their God shall stand firm and take action.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wise among the people shall give understanding to many; for some days, however, they shall fall by sword and flame and suffer captivity and plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they fall, they shall receive a little help, and many shall join them insincerely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the wise shall fall, so that they may be refined, purified, and cleansed, until the time of the end, for there is still an interval until the time appointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The king shall act as he pleases. He shall exalt himself and consider himself greater than any god and shall speak horrendous things against the God of gods. He shall prosper until the period of wrath is completed, for what is determined shall be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall pay no respect to the gods of his ancestors or to the one beloved by women; he shall pay no respect to any other god, for he shall consider himself greater than all.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall honor the god of fortresses instead of these; a god whom his ancestors did not know he shall honor with gold and silver, with precious stones and costly gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall deal with the strongest fortresses with the help of a foreign god. Those who acknowledge him he shall make more wealthy and shall appoint them as rulers over many and shall distribute the land for a price.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At the time of the end the king of the south shall attack him. But the king of the north shall rush upon him like a whirlwind, with chariots and horsemen and with many ships. He shall advance against countries and pass through like a flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall come into the beautiful land, and tens of thousands shall fall victim, but Edom and Moab and the main part of the Ammonites shall escape from his power.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall stretch out his hand against the countries, and the land of Egypt shall not escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall gain control of the treasures of gold and of silver and all the riches of Egypt, and the Libyans and the Cushites shall follow in his train.
speaker: Narrator

text: But reports from the east and the north shall alarm him, and he shall go out with great fury to bring ruin and complete destruction to many.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall pitch his palatial tents between the sea and the beautiful holy mountain. Yet he shall come to his end, with no one to help him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time Michael, the great prince, the protector of your people, shall arise. There shall be a time of anguish such as has never occurred since nations first came into existence. But at that time your people shall be delivered, everyone who is found written in the book.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of those who sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake, some to everlasting life and some to shame and everlasting contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are wise shall shine like the brightness of the sky, and those who lead the many to righteousness, like the stars forever and ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, Daniel, keep the words secret and the book sealed until the time of the end. Many shall be running back and forth, and evil shall increase.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I, Daniel, looked, and two others appeared, one standing on this bank of the stream and one on the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them said to the man clothed in linen, who was upstream, “How long shall it be until the end of these wonders?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man clothed in linen, who was upstream, raised his right hand and his left hand toward heaven. And I heard him swear by the one who lives forever that it would be for a time, two times, and half a time and that when the shattering of the power of the holy people comes to an end all these things would be accomplished.
speaker: Narrator

text: I heard but could not understand, so I said, “My lord, what shall be the outcome of these things?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Go your way, Daniel, for the words are to remain secret and sealed until the time of the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many shall be purified, cleansed, and refined, but the wicked shall continue to act wickedly. None of the wicked shall understand, but those who are wise shall understand.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the time that the regular burnt offering is taken away and the desolating sacrilege is set up, there shall be one thousand two hundred ninety days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Happy are those who persevere and attain the thousand three hundred thirty-five days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, go your way, and rest; you shall rise for your reward at the end of the days.”
speaker: Narrator
